title: Iraqi government used snipers to kill demonstrators during recent protests
text:
The Iraqi security forces have used sniper fire to kill anti-government protesters, a new report has claimed.

Amnesty International said they spoke to eight activists, protesters and journalists from Baghdad, Najaf, and Diwaniya, some of whom said sniper fire is being used to pick off protesters.

One protester from Baghdad described how a suspected sniper targeted a protester and then fired at others who tried to help him.

'There was a person who was hit by the sniper. Five people ran towards him to help and they were all shot one after the other. There were bodies all along the street. They all had shots in the head and chest,' he said.

An injured protester is rushed to the hospital after being shot during a demonstration in Baghdad, Iraq. Protesters, journalists and activists have accused the security forces of using sniper fire to kill dissenters

Iraqi security forces close streets to prevent anti-government protesters from reaching Tahrir Square in central Baghdad, Iraq. The protests have now been raging for nine days though there was some lull in the intensity today. According to the witnesses, the sniper fire was coming from behind the line of the security forces

Footage verified by the Human Rights NGO was consistent with the location and witness’ description of the incident. However, the organization has not been able to verify the identity or affiliation of the snipers.

On 6 October, the Iraqi authorities blamed 'anonymous snipers' for the killing of protesters, but witnesses said the sniper fire was coming from behind the line of security forces.

And in none of the reported cases of sniper fire are security forces known to have protected protesters, nor have police intervened and arrested anyone responsible for firing at demonstrations.

One protester told Amnesty International: 'How can the government say they do not know who the sniper is? And if the forces did not know, once they realized that why did they not warn the protesters? The forces were focused on making sure no one helped the injured.'

Mourners pray over the flag-draped coffin of a protester killed during anti-government protesters during his funeral at the Imam Ali shrine in Najaf, Iraq. Several policemen have also died during the protests. Witnesses in Baghdad have said that police surrounded the activists before opening fire on them

Witnesses from the capital also described what they believed to be sniper fire at the protests between Thursday 3 October and Sunday 6 October.

They also reported armed men shooting at protesters and driving towards them in an apparent attempt to run them over. Witnesses in Baghdad also described security forces surrounding protesters in the city’s Za’faraniya district and opening continuous live fire on them.

The security forces have accused gunmen of hiding among demonstrators to shoot at police. Several policeman have died.

It is the deadliest unrest Iraq has seen since the declared defeat of Islamic State in 2017 and has shaken the year-old government of Prime Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi

The protests over unfair distribution of jobs, lack of services and government corruption erupted on Tuesday in Baghdad and quickly spread to other Iraqi cities, mainly in the south.

It is the deadliest unrest Iraq has seen since the declared defeat of Islamic State in 2017 and has shaken the year-old government of Prime Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi.

The government has responded with vague reform promises that are unlikely to placate Iraqis.
description: The Iraqi Security Forces are using sniper fire on protesters, a new report has claimed. Amnesty International said they spoke to eight witnesses and verified footage of the sniper shots.
